title: ITV strikes £100m deal to buy up Northern Ireland's UTV television business
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 19, 2015, 09:29 BST - UK Markets close in 7 hrs 1 mins ITV strikes £100m deal to buy up Northern Ireland's UTV television business By Mehreen Khan | Telegraph – 15 minutes ago 180.75 +7.2500 
Commercial broadcaster acquires the brand to cement its move to drama and factual programmes made in Britain 
ITV (LSE: ITV.L - news ) has agreed a £100m deal to buy the UTV media brand - Northern Ireland's most-watched television channel. 
Britain's biggest commercial broadcaster said the move would allow it to expand its "free to air business" and would lead to efficiency savings across its network. 
The deal, which does not include UTV's radio arms, is still subject to approval from regulator Ofcom and Irish competition authorities. 
UTV confirmed in August that it was in discussions regarding the sale of its television assets. The Belfast-based broadcaster - which produces some of Northern Ireland's most popular shows - has struggled in recent months. 
The company launched its nationwide UTV Ireland station in January. But it has had a disappointing start, reporting half-year losses of £7.5m this year. The group as a whole, UTV Media (LSE: UTV.L - news ) , reported pre-tax profits £5.5m last year. 
ITV's acquisition cements its shift in focus from reality television and entertainment producers in the US, to drama and factual programme makers in the UK If approved, ITV will own 13 of the 15 regional licences for the Channel 3 network across the UK. 
Chief executive Adam Crozier said: "We are pleased that they are joining the ITV family. 
"We have a long-standing relationship with UTV, which has been the leading commercial broadcaster in Northern Ireland for many years thanks to its strong regional identity and blend of excellent local programming". 
John McCann, chief executive of UTV Media, said: "Becoming part of the ITV Family is by far the best way to take UTV's television business forward with an ongoing focus to provide brilliant television to viewers right across Ireland (Other OTC: IRLD - news ) ."
